$!You may need to tell DVLA if you have cancer.$!

%You can be fined up to £1,000 if you don’t tell DVLA about a medical condition that affects your driving. If you’re involved in an accident, you may be prosecuted.%

##Car or motorcycle licence##

You don't need to tell DVLA if you have cancer, unless:

- you develop problems with the brain or nervous system
- your doctor expresses concerns about your fitness to drive
- you're restricted to certain types of vehicles or vehicles that have been adapted for you
- your medication causes side effects likely to affect safe driving

If you develop any problems that may affect your safe driving you will need to tell DVLA. Fill in form G1 and send it to DVLA. The address on the form. 

$D[Download 'Questionnaire G1 - Confidential medical information' (PDF, 314K)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_065614.pdf "Questionnaire G1"){:rel="external"}$D


##Bus, coach or lorry licence##

You must tell DVLA. Fill in form C1V and send it to DVLA. The address is on the form.

$D
[Download ‘C1V - Confidential medical information’ (PDF, 260KB)](http://www.direct.gov.uk/prod_consum_dg/groups/dg_digitalassets/@dg/@en/@motor/documents/digitalasset/dg_179266.pdf "Download medical questionnaire"){:rel="external"}
$D

*[DVLA]: Driver Vehicle and Licensing Agency
overview: You may need to tell DVLA if you have cancer - if you do, download the correct form to let them know
title: Cancer and driving
